document.masterDocTitle: Immature stages of three Japanese species of the genus Plecia Wiedemann (Diptera: Bibionidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Immature stages of three Japanese species of the genus Plecia Wiedemann (Diptera: Bibionidae)

bibRefCitation.author: Hardy
bibRefCitation.refString: Hardy, D. E. & Takahashi, M. (1960) Revision of the Japanese Bibionidae (Diptera, Nematocera). Pacific Insects, 2, 383 - 449.

subSubSection.paragraph: Egg : Shiny brown, with smooth surface, 0.68–0.73 mm long ( n = 20 ).

Final­instar larva : Genae with 6 setae anteriorly and 16 sensory pits dorsally including 8 sensory pits along ecdysial suture (
Fig. 5
D: 4–7 ). Frontal apotome with 2 setae and 4 sensory pits (
Fig. 5
D: 1–3 ). Clypeus with 4 setae and 6 sensory pits dorsally (
Fig. 5
D). Labrum with 2 small papillae and 2 sensory pits dorsally, about 6 small papillae and fine setae on its anterior membranous part (
Fig. 5
D). Epipharynx (
Fig. 5
E) with many fine setae, small conical processes, 2 rows of denticles, 8 small papillae and 4 sensory pits. Mandible (
Figs. 5
F, G) with 3 blunt teeth (teeth may be rather worn by feeding activity) bearing 3 setae and 2 dorsal sensory pits, well­developed prostheca attached inside. Cardo with 3 setae and sensory pit ventrally (
Fig. 5
J). Galeolacinia nearly trapezoidal in shape, with conical projection anteriorly (
Figs.
5
I, J); dorsal surface with fine setae, row of spinules, small digitiform process, and 6–7 sensory pits (
Fig.
5
I); ventral surface with 2 setae and row of denticles anteriorly (
Fig. 5
J). Stipes composed of 3 parts: proximal isolated appendage, middle sclerite with ventral sensory pit and dorsal U­shaped invagination, and distal membranous portion with some spinules, sensory pit, and seta (
Figs.
5
I, J). Maxillary palpus with sensory pit and 10–12 apical papillae, one of which is larger than others (
Fig. 5
J). Central membranous area of labium with 12 small papillae and fine setae on its anterior margin (
Fig. 5
H). Hypopharynx nearly elliptical in shape with some pubescence (
Fig. 5
H). Body dark brown, arrangement of processes as shown in
Table 1
a. Plate­like ventral swelling of prothorax (
Fig. 5
B) with 5 processes. Body cuticle covered with many spinules (
Fig. 5
C). Width of head capsule 0.90–1.12 mm (mean ± SD = 1.02 ± 0.07 mm , n = 34 ;
Fig. 7
b); Body length approximately 17–19 mm (measured from exuviae).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7 . Width of head capsule of final­instar larva. a:
P. adiastola
; larvae were collected from several locations. b:
P. hadrosoma
; larval exuviae were collected from a cluster of pupae. Two peaks in b indicate that the size difference between males and females (males<females) is apparent in the final­instar larva.

TABLE 1 . Arrangement of the processes on the body segments. a: final­instar larva, b: pupa. T: thorax, A: abdomen. Arrangement of the processes is divided into dorsal, lateral, and ventral parts except for T1 and A9. Dorsal and ventral processes of each of T2–A8 of the final­instar larva are subdivided into anterior, medial, and posterior rows. Venter of A1 and A2 of the pupa are covered by the leg and wing sheaths.

subSubSection.paragraph: T 1 T 2 T 3 A 1 A 2 A 3 A 4 A 5 A 6 A 7 A 8 A 9
